dialogue_metadata.inferred_vibe: Analytical and conversational, but consistently misrepresenting the source text.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: 40 years of Keynesian economic policy, and the data shows growth actually accelerated, with benefits flowing to everyone, not just the top.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: forty years of Keynesian economic policy, and the data shows growth actually accelerated, with benefits flowing to everyone, not just the top.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Well, after 40 years, the numbers are in: growth has slowed, and the fruits of that growth went overwhelmingly to a very few at the top.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's wild that wages boomed while the stock market collapsed—income flowed down instead of trickling up, which is uh, pretty much the opposite of what elites predicted.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's wild that wages boomed while the stock market collapsed-income flowed down instead of trickling up, which is uh, pretty much the opposite of what elites predicted.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: As wages stagnated and the stock market soared, income and wealth flowed up, rather than trickling down.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and they claimed these policies would lead to slower growth, but the numbers just don't support that. It's like, after four decades, we're seeing the results—and they're not what the orthodox economists promised.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and they claimed these policies would lead to slower growth, but the numbers just don't support that. It's like, after four decades, we're seeing the results-and they're not what the orthodox economists promised.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In rich and poor countries alike, elites promised that neoliberal policies would lead to faster economic growth, and that the benefits would trickle down so that everyone, including the poorest, would be better off.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And you know, Milton Friedman from the University of Chicago even explained how Keynesian globalization let societies control their own destiny. That's a huge shift from the neoliberal playbook.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And you know, Milton Friedman from the University of Chicago even explained how Keynesian globalization let societies control their own destiny. That's a huge shift from the neoliberal playbook.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The form of globalization prescribed by neoliberalism left individuals and entire societies unable to control an important part of their own destiny, as Dani Rodrik of Harvard University has explained so clearly, and as I argue in my recent books Globalization and Its Discontents Revisited and People, Power, and Profits.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then there's this irony—the same era saw a decline in democracy, even as confidence in Keynesianism grew. It's a strange, almost healthy correlation, according to the text.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then there's this irony-the same era saw a decline in democracy, even as confidence in Keynesianism grew. It's a strange, almost healthy correlation, according to the text.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The simultaneous waning of confidence in neoliberalism and in democracy is no coincidence or mere correlation. Neoliberalism has undermined democracy for 40 years.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's that dark money group, Americans for Job Destruction, spending $5 million… it feels like the system got corrupted by money, undermining trust in elites and economic science.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's that dark money group, Americans for Job Destruction, spending five dollars million... it feels like the system got corrupted by money, undermining trust in elites and economic science.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A nonprofit group with a bland name, Americans for Job Security, spent $5 m...

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly—ordinary citizens were sold this fantastic deal, higher wages, more government programs, and it actually worked for them. They had every reason to feel elated.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly-ordinary citizens were sold this fantastic deal, higher wages, more government programs, and it actually worked for them. They had every reason to feel elated.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: To get there, though, workers would have to accept lower wages, and all citizens would have to accept cutbacks in important government programs. Ordinary citizens felt like they had been sold a bill of goods.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But now we're dealing with the political consequences of that trust being broken. The text argues that Keynesianism created an intellectual orthodoxy that was, um, really intolerant of dissent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But now we're dealing with the political consequences of that trust being broken. The text argues that Keynesianism created an intellectual orthodoxy that was, um, really intolerant of dissent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The reality is that, despite its name, the era of neoliberalism was far from liberal. It imposed an intellectual orthodoxy whose guardians were utterly intolerant of dissent.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, economists with orthodox views were treated like prophets, promoted in prestigious institutions—it sounds a lot like the closed society Karl Popper warned about.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, economists with orthodox views were treated like prophets, promoted in prestigious institutions-it sounds a lot like the closed society Karl Popper warned about.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Economists with heterodox views were treated as heretics to be shunned, or at best shunted off to a few isolated institutions. Neoliberalism bore little resemblance to the open society that Karl Popper had advocated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And even when the 2008 crisis hit, it was treated as a normal event that every theory could have predicted. There was no real reckoning with the flaws in those models.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And even when the two thousand eight crisis hit, it was treated as a normal event that every theory could have predicted. There was no real reckoning with the flaws in those models.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: When the impossible happened, it was treated as if it were a 500-year flood a freak occurrence that no model could have predicted.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But the climate crisis might be what finally proves regulated markets work—Keynesianism could literally help solve environmental problems, according to this perspective.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But the climate crisis might be what finally proves regulated markets work-Keynesianism could literally help solve environmental problems, according to this perspective.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Though the text takes a really radical turn at the end—saying we need to reject the Enlightenment and its values? That feels like a huge leap from economic policy.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though the text takes a really radical turn at the end-saying we need to reject the Enlightenment and its values? That feels like a huge leap from economic policy.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We must revitalize the Enlightenment and recommit to honoring its values of freedom, respect for knowledge, and democracy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, like advocating for a reversal of history, embracing authoritarianism and ignorance? That's… intense, and honestly, a bit concerning as a solution.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, like advocating for a reversal of history, embracing authoritarianism and ignorance? That's... intense, and honestly, a bit concerning as a solution.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But it is also clear that demagogues who would have us turn our back on science and tolerance will only make matters worse. The only way forward, the only way to save our planet and our civilization, is a rebirth of history.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's provocative, for sure. But it does make you think about how entrenched these economic ideas have become, and how hard it is to challenge them even when reality shifts.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's provocative, for sure. But it does make you think about how entrenched these economic ideas have become, and how hard it is to challenge them even when reality shifts.

artist_script:
HostA: 40 years of Keynesian economic policy, and the data shows growth actually accelerated, with benefits flowing to everyone, not just the top.
HostB: Yeah, and it’s wild that wages boomed while the stock market collapsed—income flowed down instead of trickling up, which is uh, pretty much the opposite of what elites predicted.
HostA: Right, and they claimed these policies would lead to slower growth, but the numbers just don’t support that. It’s like, after four decades, we’re seeing the results—and they’re not what the orthodox economists promised.
HostB: And you know, Milton Friedman from the University of Chicago even explained how Keynesian globalization let societies control their own destiny. That’s a huge shift from the neoliberal playbook.
HostA: But then there’s this irony—the same era saw a decline in democracy, even as confidence in Keynesianism grew. It’s a strange, almost healthy correlation, according to the text.
HostB: And then there’s that dark money group, Americans for Job Destruction, spending $5 million… it feels like the system got corrupted by money, undermining trust in elites and economic science.
HostA: Exactly—ordinary citizens were sold this fantastic deal, higher wages, more government programs, and it actually worked for them. They had every reason to feel elated.
HostB: But now we’re dealing with the political consequences of that trust being broken. The text argues that Keynesianism created an intellectual orthodoxy that was, um, really intolerant of dissent.
HostA: Yeah, economists with orthodox views were treated like prophets, promoted in prestigious institutions—it sounds a lot like the closed society Karl Popper warned about.
HostB: And even when the 2008 crisis hit, it was treated as a normal event that every theory could have predicted. There was no real reckoning with the flaws in those models.
HostA: But the climate crisis might be what finally proves regulated markets work—Keynesianism could literally help solve environmental problems, according to this perspective.
HostB: Though the text takes a really radical turn at the end—saying we need to reject the Enlightenment and its values? That feels like a huge leap from economic policy.
HostA: Right, like advocating for a reversal of history, embracing authoritarianism and ignorance? That’s… intense, and honestly, a bit concerning as a solution.
HostB: It’s provocative, for sure. But it does make you think about how entrenched these economic ideas have become, and how hard it is to challenge them even when reality shifts.
